message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Using Reachable Sets for Trajectory Planning of Automated Vehicles
Paper Abstract: The computational effort of trajectory planning for automated vehicles often increases with the complexity of the traffic situation. This is particularly problematic in safety-critical situations, in which the vehicle must react in a timely manner. We present a novel motion planning approach for automated vehicles, which combines set-based reachability analysis with convex optimization to address this issue. This combination makes it possible to find driving maneuvers even in small and convoluted solution spaces. In contrast to existing work, the computation time of our approach typically decreases, the more complex situations become. We demonstrate the benefits of our motion planner in scenarios from the CommonRoad benchmark suite and validate the approach on a real test vehicle.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Trajectory optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajectory_optimization"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Kinodynamic planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinodynamic_planning"},{"title":"Wavefront expansion algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavefront_expansion_algorithm"},{"title":"Trajectory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajectory"},{"title":"Motor planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_planning"},{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Any-angle_path_planning"},{"title":"Trajectoid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajectoid"},{"title":"Motor coordination - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_coordination"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of trajectory planning:

## Definition and Scope

Trajectory planning is the process of designing a trajectory that minimizes (or maximizes) some measure of performance while satisfying a set of constraints.(no content)It is a technique for computing an open-loop solution to an optimal control problem.

## Applications

There are a wide variety of applications for trajectory planning, primarily in robotics: industry, manipulation, walking, path-planning, and aerospace. Specific examples include:

- Robotic manipulators with redundant systems, where trajectory optimization can be used to avoid obstacles or minimize joint torque.
- Trajectory optimization is often used to compute trajectories for quadrotor helicopters.
- Autonomous vehicles for cars and trucks that must respect acceleration, steering, and velocity limits, and aerial robotics for unmanned aerial vehicles with dynamic constraints.

## Related Concepts

Kinodynamic planning is a class of problems for which velocity, acceleration, and force/torque bounds must be satisfied, together with kinematic constraints such as avoiding obstacles. This is particularly relevant when physical constraints must be considered in trajectory design.

## Methods

Popular approaches include extensions of RRT algorithms such as RRT* for kinodynamic systems, and sampling-based methods like Model Predictive Path Integral (MPPI) control.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Reachability analysis"

Links: [{"title":"Reachability analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_analysis"},{"title":"Reachability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability"},{"title":"Reachability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_problem"},{"title":"Context-free language reachability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context-free_language_reachability"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Petri net - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petri_net"},{"title":"Reaching definition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reaching_definition"},{"title":"International Conference on Reachability Problems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Reachability_Problems"},{"title":"Petri net unfoldings - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petri_net_unfoldings"},{"title":"Control-flow graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-flow_graph"}]

Here are the search results for "Reachability analysis":

## Overview

Reachability analysis is a solution to the reachability problem in the context of distributed systems, used to determine which global states can be reached by a distributed system consisting of local entities that communicate by exchanging messages.

## Key Concepts

The result of reachability analysis is a global state transition graph (also called reachability graph) which shows all global states of the distributed system that are reachable from the initial global state, and all possible sequences of send, consume and service interactions performed by the local entities.(no content)More broadly, reachability is a fundamental problem which can be formulated as follows: Given a computational system with a set of allowed rules or transformations, decide whether a certain state of a system is reachable from a given initial state of the system.

## Applications and Challenges

The transition graph can be used for checking general design flaws of the protocol, but also for verifying that the sequences of service interactions by the entities correspond to the requirements given by the global service specification of the system.

One significant challenge in reachability analysis is the "state space explosion problem - if two entities of a protocol have 100 states each, and the medium may include 10 types of messages, up to two in each direction, the number of global states in the reachability graph can reach 100 million.(no content)A number of tools have been developed to automatically perform reachability analysis and model checking on the reachability graph.

Web search results for query: "Convex optimization"

Links: [{"title":"Convex optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_optimization"},{"title":"Category:Convex optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Convex_optimization"},{"title":"Talk:Convex optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Convex_optimization"},{"title":"Conic optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conic_optimization"},{"title":"Convex function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_function"},{"title":"Convex analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_analysis"},{"title":"Template:Boyd Vandenberghe Convex Optimization 2004 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Boyd_Vandenberghe_Convex_Optimization_2004"},{"title":"Perturbation function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_function"},{"title":"Biconvex optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biconvex_optimization"},{"title":"Duality (optimization) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duality_(optimization)"}]

I've completed the web search for "Convex optimization." Here's what I found:

## Overview

Convex optimization is a subfield of mathematical optimization that studies the problem of minimizing convex functions over convex sets (or, equivalently, maximizing concave functions over convex sets).

## Key Properties

Every point that is local minimum is also a global minimum in convex optimization problems, which is a significant advantage over non-convex optimization.

## Solution Methods

The field includes various approaches:

- The convex programs easiest to solve are the unconstrained problems, or the problems with only equality constraints. As the equality constraints are all linear, they can be eliminated with linear algebra and integrated into the objective, thus converting an equality-constrained problem into an unconstrained one.

- Gradient descent (a special case of steepest descent) is an efficient algorithm for unconstrained minimization.

- A common way to solve problems with inequality constraints is to reduce them to unconstrained problems by adding a barrier function, enforcing the inequality constraints, to the objective function. Such methods are called interior point methods.

## Applications

Convex optimization can be used to model problems in portfolio optimization, worst-case risk analysis, optimal advertising, variations of statistical regression (including regularization and quantile regression), model fitting (particularly multiclass classification), and electricity generation optimization.

Convex optimization is a subfield of mathematical optimization that studies the problem of minimizing convex functions over convex sets (or, equivalently, maximizing concave functions over convex sets).

## Key Properties

Every point that is local minimum is also a global minimum in convex optimization problems, which is a significant advantage over non-convex optimization.

## Solution Methods

The field includes various approaches:

- The convex programs easiest to solve are the unconstrained problems, or the problems with only equality constraints. As the equality constraints are all linear, they can be eliminated with linear algebra and integrated into the objective, thus converting an equality-constrained problem into an unconstrained one.

- Gradient descent (a special case of steepest descent) is an efficient algorithm for unconstrained minimization.

- A common way to solve problems with inequality constraints is to reduce them to unconstrained problems by adding a barrier function, enforcing the inequality constraints, to the objective function. Such methods are called interior point methods.

## Applications

Convex optimization can be used to model problems in portfolio optimization, worst-case risk analysis, optimal advertising, variations of statistical regression (including regularization and quantile regression), model fitting (particularly multiclass classification), and electricity generation optimization.

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"File:Motion planning workspace 1 configuration space 2.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_workspace_1_configuration_space_2.svg"},{"title":"File:Motion planning workspace 1 configuration space 1.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_workspace_1_configuration_space_1.svg"},{"title":"File:Motion planning workspace 1.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_workspace_1.svg"},{"title":"File:Motion planning configuration space road map path.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_configuration_space_road_map_path.svg"},{"title":"Kinodynamic planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinodynamic_planning"},{"title":"OMPL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OMPL"},{"title":"Category:Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"Topological complexity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_complexity"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of motion planning:

## Definition and Core Concept

A basic motion planning problem is to compute a continuous path that connects a start configuration S and a goal configuration G, while avoiding collision with known obstacles.

## Applications

Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields, such as animating digital characters, video game, architectural design, robotic surgery, and the study of biological molecules.

## Key Concepts

The robot and obstacle geometry is described in a 2D or 3D workspace, while the motion is represented as a path in (possibly higher-dimensional) configuration space.(no content)A configuration describes the pose of the robot, and the configuration space C is the set of all possible configurations.

## Algorithms and Approaches

Motion planning employs several algorithmic approaches:

- **Grid-based algorithms**: Grid-based approaches overlay a grid on configuration space and assume each configuration is identified with a grid point. At each grid point, the robot is allowed to move to adjacent grid points as long as the line between them is completely contained within Cfree (this is tested with collision detection). This discretizes the set of actions, and search algorithms (like A*) are used to find a path from the start to the goal.

- **Sampling-based algorithms**: Sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces, and have been applied to problems which have dozens or even hundreds of dimensions (robotic manipulators, biological molecules, animated digital characters, and legged robots).

Links: [{"title":"Cruise (autonomous vehicle) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cruise_(autonomous_vehicle)"},{"title":"Autonomous underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_underwater_vehicle"},{"title":"Self-driving car - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-driving_car"},{"title":"List of predictions for autonomous Tesla vehicles by Elon Musk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_predictions_for_autonomous_Tesla_vehicles_by_Elon_Musk"},{"title":"Vehicular automation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicular_automation"},{"title":"Autonomous aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_aircraft"},{"title":"Autonomous racing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_racing"},{"title":"Waymo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waymo"},{"title":"Wayve - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wayve"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of autonomous vehicles based on the search results:

## Definition and Overview

A self-driving car, also known as an autonomous car, driverless car, robotic car or robo-car, is a car that is capable of operating with reduced or no human input.(no content)They are sometimes called robotaxis, though this term refers specifically to self-driving cars operated for a ridesharing company.

## Levels of Autonomy

The Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) classifies road vehicle autonomy in six levels: Level 1 involves driver assistance where the vehicle controls steering or speed autonomously in specific circumstances; Level 2 involves partial automation where the vehicle controls both steering and speed autonomously in specific circumstances; Level 3 involves conditional automation where the vehicle controls both steering and speed under normal environmental conditions but requires the driver to be ready to take control in other circumstances; Level 4 involves high automation where the vehicle travels autonomously under normal environmental conditions without requiring driver oversight; and Level 5 involves full autonomy where the vehicle can complete travel autonomously in any environmental conditions.

## Key Technology

Autonomous vehicle software contains several modules that work together: the perception module ingests and processes data from sensors like cameras, LIDAR, RADAR, and ultrasonic SONAR; the localization module uses 3D point cloud data, GPS, IMU, and mapping information to determine the vehicle's precise position; and the planning module takes inputs from both perception and localization to compute actions. These modules are supported by machine learning algorithms, particularly deep neural networks.

## Current Market Leaders

Waymo operates commercial robotaxi services available to the public in Phoenix, the San Francisco Bay Area, Los Angeles, Atlanta, and Austin, and as of December 2025, operates over 450,000 rides per week.(no content)Wayve Technologies Ltd is a British autonomous driving technology company focused on developing self-driving vehicle systems through end-to-end deep learning, using a self-learning "AI driver" that learns from camera data and driving experience.
